title: Which hit songs were better than the album versions? - Quora

response.answer_text: “Which hit songs were better than the album versions?” The first song that comes to mind for me is Cheap Trick’s “I Want You to Want Me”. Originally from their second album “In Color”, it was the first single from but completely failed to chart in the U.S.. It did, however, do well in Japan which led to a tour there where their live album “Cheap Trick at Budokan” was recorded. That version became a massive hit int the U.S. and catapulted them to stardom. Although they’re the same song, the two versions are completely different. The original version is more directly upbeat and relies much more on piano. There’s no piano on the live version, and it’s a much more powerful version done by a band at the height of their skills. Rick Nielsen’s guitar parts on the original seem almost phoned-in, whereas they’re brilliant and burning on the live album. Don’t just take what I say as truth though, listen to them for yourself!
Not a hit, but I preferred the original 1989 version of Sit Down by James ( Number 77, number 2 in the Indie charts) to the 1991 version which was a hit Number 2) and appeared on Gold Mother
